Award.AwardTitle: STEM in the New Millennium: Preparation, Pathways, and Diversity

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
In this Step type 2 project, the investigators are examining evidence for educational pathways to STEM careers using several different sources of national survey data. They are studying how high school course taking, test scores, and type of school attended is related to later career choice in college. They are examining the diversity of preparation for college for students of different backgrounds, the connection between STEM degree attainment and college credits and early college performance, and they are examining the connection between work experience during undergraduate years and STEM labor force entry.

The researchers are using well-known national longitudinal survey data of high school and college students as well as conducting a new survey of students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This study investigated what schools can do to increase diversity in STEM education and the workforce. Researchers used several nationally representative databases that follow high school students as they transition through college. Data spanned four decades, from 1980 through 2009, including the high school class of 1982, 1992, 2002, and 2004. Researchers examined how students’ academic preparation—especially their coursework—along with the attitudes, interests, and social interactions with others impacted students’ persistence in STEM. Below are highlights of findings from the study.

 

(1) Physical science and engineering majors are dominated by men, and not only by white men but by minorities as well. After accounting for differences in academic preparation in high school (including grades, test scores, and coursework), black males are actually more than two times as likely to declare a physical science/engineering major than white males, and black females are closer than white females to closing the gap with white males. This study, which was published in the journal Educational Researcher, suggests the possible value of investing in math instruction that increases the K-12 preparation of students of color in mathematics.

 

(2) Considerable effort and attention has been devoted to enhancing mathematics curriculum and course taking in high schools, and our findings suggest that advanced math course taking (in trigonometry, pre-calculus and calculus) has increased substantially among the growing population of high school graduates who attend 4-year colleges and universities.  Specifically, the portion of US high school graduates entering 4-year colleges and universities that are prepared to study STEM fields in college has tripled during the last 20 years. In 1982, only 43% had taken pre-calculus or calculus compared to 66% of 2004 4-year college matriculates. During the same period, the portion of STEM-ready matriculates who majored in STEM declined, from 33% to 20%. Advanced high school math courses have always provided valuable background for students entering STEM fields in college. These findings suggest that non-STEM fields are attracting students who have a strong mathematics background. 

 

(3) The possibility of bias in high school math teachers’ exhibit assessments of their students was investigated. We found that disparities in teachers’ ratings favoring white males over both minority male and females disappear once the white male advantage in grades and test scores is taken into account. However, we also found a consistent bias against white females, such that teachers believe that math is easier for white males than for white females. This research, published in the journal Gender and Society, informs theories of gendered status expectations, finding that bias and stereotypes continue to exist in contemporary high school math classrooms.

 

(4) The growth and geographic diversification of the school-age Latino population suggest that schools in areas that previously had very few Latinos now provide the primary source of education for these students. This study uses the 1999-2000 Schools and Staffing Survey and the Educational Longitudinal Study of 2002 to compare public high schools in new and established Latino destinations. We examine school characteristics, instructional resources, and access to advanced math courses. We find that schools in new destinations display more favorable educational contexts according to a number of measures, but offer fewer linguistic support services than schools in established destinations.
